name: Tai Chi
summary: A traditional Chinese mind-body practice combining slow, flowing movements, deep breathing, and focused attention to improve balance, relaxation, and overall health.
description: Tai Chi (Taijiquan) is a traditional Chinese martial art and mind-body exercise characterized by slow, graceful, and continuous movements coordinated with breath and mental focus. Originally developed as a martial practice, it is now widely practiced worldwide for its health benefits, including stress reduction, balance enhancement, improved flexibility, and overall well-being. Tai Chi emphasizes mindful movement, postural alignment, and the cultivation of 'Qi' (vital energy). Research supports its role in fall prevention among older adults, management of chronic pain, and adjunctive therapy for conditions such as anxiety, hypertension, and fibromyalgia. It is gentle, adaptable, and safe across a wide range of ages and fitness levels.

sections.text: Tai Chi combines slow, mindful movement with controlled breathing and mental focus, promoting balance, flexibility, and relaxation. Physiologically, it improves proprioception, enhances vestibular and neuromuscular coordination, reduces sympathetic nervous system activity, and increases parasympathetic tone. Psychologically, it fosters mindfulness and stress reduction. In Traditional Chinese Medicine, Tai Chi regulates Qi flow through the meridians, promoting harmony and health.

sections.preparation: Comfortable clothing, flat supportive shoes or barefoot, quiet environment.
procedure: Begin with centering and breathing exercises.
Practice a sequence of slow, flowing movements (forms) coordinated with breath.
Maintain focus on posture, alignment, and mindful awareness.
Conclude with standing meditation or relaxation.
sections.frequency: 2–3 times per week recommended for health benefits; daily practice ideal.
sections.total_treatment_time: 8–12 weeks for initial learning; long-term practice yields cumulative benefits.
